org.xtext.xrobot.api

Class RobotPosition

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.xtext.xrobot.api.RobotPosition

  • @Data
public class RobotPosition
extends java.lang.Object
    The position of a robot, including its Cartesian coordinates x and y, the actual speed, the view direction, and the actual rotation speed. The coordinates can be converted to a Vector using toVector().

    The coordinates are in centimeters relative to the center of the arena. The reference point is the center of the robot's axis. As opposed to screen coordinates, robots use a right-handed coordinate system, i.e. the vertical axis points upward. The speed is given as a Vector in this coordinate system with the unit centimeters per second. The view direction is given in degrees in the range between -180° to 180°. The angle is interpreted mathematically, that means a vector with angle 0 points to the right and increasing the angle corresponds to a counter-clockwise rotation. The rotation speed is in degrees per second.

    • Method Detail

      • toVector

        public Vector toVector()
        Create a vector from the x and y coordinates of the robot position. The length of this vector corresponds to the distance of the robot's axis from the center of the arena.
        Returns:
        a vector corresponding to the absolute position of the robot

      • getRelativePosition

        public Vector getRelativePosition(Vector position)
        Compute the bearing to the given position taking the viewDirection into account. This means that the given position vector is translated into the local coordinate system of this robot. If the given position is directly in front of this robot, the resulting vector has an angle of 0.
        Parameters:
        position - a position to use as reference point
        Returns:
        a vector to the given position from the perspective of this robot

      • getRelativeSpeed

        public Vector getRelativeSpeed(Vector speed)
        Compute the relative speed taking the viewDirection into account. For example, given a RobotPosition instance p, 
         p.relativeSpeed(p.actualSpeed)
        yields the robot's own speed relative to its orientation. If this resulting speed vector has an angle of 90° it means that the robot is moving sideways to the left, so probably the opponent robot is pushing it from the right side.
        Parameters:
        speed - a speed vector
        Returns:
        the corresponding speed vector from the perspective of this robot
